title: 103_hr3120
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crime Victims' Bill of Rights Act". Victims are allowed to make statements in federal cases. Rule 32 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to address personally any victim of the offense at the sentencing hearing. Rule 32 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to allow victims to request an in camera statement at the sentencing hearing. SEC. 3. Victims of state offenses have the right to be informed about victim compensation and assistance programs. State must provide effective notice to crime victims about available programs. SEC. 4. Victims have rights in court proceedings. Section 501(b) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include programs allowing for the physical and visual separation of crime victims from alleged perpetrators in judicial facilities. Section 506 is amended to require states to comply with victim separation programs to avoid a 25% reduction in grant funds. In the fiscal year beginning after September 30, 1994, victims of crime must be notified and provided with visual and physical separation from alleged perpetrators while waiting in judicial facilities. They should also receive early notice of court proceedings and parole hearings and be personally addressed before sentencing. At sentencing hearings, victims of crime or their representatives have the opportunity to address the court and provide information related to the sentence. Federal victims have rights to be informed about compensation programs and have access to separate waiting facilities. The Attorney General ensures that Federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials provide crime victims with notice of available assistance programs, offer separation from alleged perpetrators in judicial facilities, and notify victims of court proceedings promptly. The Attorney General ensures that crime victims are notified promptly of court proceedings or parole hearings they are required or entitled to attend.
